Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. Credit only on completion of FREN S140. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate and Advanced Fren...
description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Priority is given to Yale students. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S130. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Culture and Conversat...
description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings; discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals; films; songs; stories; and clips from French television. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Prerequisite: after FREN 150, 151, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: May 24 - June 28.

subject: FREN
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent; and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: July 5 - August 9.

subject: FREN
title: Belle Époque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: May 31 - July 5

subject: GLBL
title: Foreign Policy and Internation...
description: This six-week course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities Global Summer Program. Two students from each partner university, including two from Yale, will be admitted to this course. Partial funding is provided for all students enrolled. The course will cover the mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and of the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 29 - August 8.

subject: GLBL
title: Introduction to Human Rights T...
long_title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German I
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Credit only on completion of GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German II
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S130. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: GMAN
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Offered in Berlin. An advanced language course focusing on improving upper level language skills through the exploration of the culture, politics, art, and history of twentieth-century Berlin. Students will accomplish this through the discussion of current events, films, a novel or play, conducting interviews and visiting sites in Berlin. Strong class participation expected. Prerequisite: GMAN S140 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, room and board costs in Germany, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 21 - July 26.

subject: GMAN
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Holocaust: Rhetoric, Film, and Politics
description: Cancelled. Political, cultural, and ideological background of the Holocaust and its representation in film, art and literature. Relationship of Nazi thought to culture, science, and technology. Aesthetics as the backbone and public face of the Holocaust. Will consider Kant, Nietzsche, Wagner, Heidegger, Kafka, Riefenstahl, Celan, Levi, Hersonski, Lanzmann, Quentin Tarantino. Readings and discussion in English. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: GMST
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: GREK
title: Beginning Greek: The Elements...
long_title: Beginning Greek: The Elements of Grammar
description: Introduction to ancient Greek. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for GREK S120. No prior knowledge of Greek assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: GREK
title: The Elements of Greek Grammar
description: Continuation of GREK S110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Greek authors. The sequence GREK S110, S120 prepares for GREK 131 or 141. Prerequisite: GREK S110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: HIST
title: History of American West
description: The history of westward expansion and of the places west of the Mississippi River, as told through the people who saw it, experienced it, and made it happen. Beginning in the colonial era and concluding in the present day, with an emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries and international comparisons. Research will include the use of materials held at the Beinecke Rare Book Library. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: HIST
title: Film, Video, and American Hist...
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include films such as The Birth of a Nation, Gold Diggers of 1933, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: HIST
title: Writing History and Nonfiction...
description: Introductory writing course in nonfiction for students who wish to write history, biography, or narrative journalism. Develops the craft of turning real events, past or present, into plot- and character-driven stories that compete with the pleasures of fiction. Examines model texts of nonfiction narratives:ÃÂtheir structure, voice, use of character, claims, and rhetorical moves. Students research, write, and revise their own nonfiction texts, set in the past or in the present, and based on archival research, interviews (where appropriate), and secondary reading. Prerequisite: a 200-level English or History course. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HIST
title: Crusades and Medieval Europe
description: Medieval Europe studied through an investigation of the Crusades movement with views of Western European, Byzantine, and Muslim participants. The significance of the Crusades to Western Europe, the Byzantine Empire, and the Muslim Near East from politcial, economic, religious, and cultural perspectives. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: HIST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Focus on Viking raids, emigration from Scandinavia (to Normandy, Newfoundland, and the Danelaw, among other places), Viking ship technology, the creation of Scandinavian kingdoms, trade, life at home in Scandinavia, religion, and art and literature. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HIST
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books...
long_title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
description: Offered in the Beinecke Rare Book Library. The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the hand-press book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of firsthand encounters with manuscripts, rare books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HIST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Course description will be available soon.

subject: HIST
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HIST
title: History of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,350. Course dates: June 29 - August 2.

subject: HIST
title: Empires of East Asia
description: Survey of the history of China, Japan, and Korea from the seventh century to the present. Focus on two separate empires: the Tang and Japanese. Attention to interactions among East Asian regions in the past and today. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: HIST
title: United States Cities in a Glob...
long_title: United States Cities in a Global Age
description: Although the global city is often considered a recent development, this course examines the long history of connections between the local space of American cities and larger global forces since the nineteenth century. We will explore how immigration, international commerce and exchange, tourism, real estate, and cultural spaces like museums and parks have made U.S. cities profoundly global spaces and how cities have been central to the history of the United States as a global power. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: HLTH
title: VisualApproachestoGlobalHealth
description: Offered in Swaziland. This course explores the intersection of global health and visual media and focuses on global health issues such as HIV, TB, human rights, and violence in public health. Students learn filmmaking as a means for translating complex public health concepts into a format approachable by a general audience. In addition to traditional learning, students work with instructors, guest lecturers, and production personnel to create a short film on a selected global health topic. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Swaziland, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: May 31 - July 5.

subject: HSAR
title: Art and Myth in Ancient Greece
long_title: Art and Myth in Ancient Greece
description: Exploration of imagery of myths on Greek works of art and architecture ranging from great temples such as the Parthenon to small objects such as painted pots. Course includes visits to Yale's collection. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: HSAR
title: Art and Revolution in the Mode...
long_title: Art and Revolution in the Modern Middle East
description: Explores the intersection of modern art and political upheaval during the last two centuries in the Modern Middle East. Spans from Napoleon's invasion of Egypt in 1798, tracing a trajectory of fine arts and visual culture in the region, to the graffiti, cartoons, and social media of the Arab Spring. Focuses on questions of the impact of political change on art and visual culture; the role of ethnicity, gender, and class in modern Middle Eastern art; and the lasting mark of colonialism, post-colonialism, and neo-colonialism on the region. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HSAR
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. The historical relationship between art and science in the West, from the Renaissance to the present. Case studies illustrate the similarities and differences between the way artists and scientists each model the world, in the studio and the laboratory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HSAR
title: Ten Works of Western Art
description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: HSAR
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HUMS
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HUMS
title: Belle Époque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: May 31 - July 5

subject: HUMS
title: Bodies in Law and Literature
description: Representations of the human body in law and literature. The complex nature of how humans think about and give meaning to their bodies in relationship to themselves and to others. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HUMS
title: Italian Language and Cinema in...
long_title: Italian Language and Cinema in Tuscany
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisa. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 22 - July 27.

subject: HUMS
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: HUMS
title: Islam and the West
description: Historical survey of the key points of contact, exchange, and contention between Islam and the Christian West from the early medieval to the modern period. Students will gain a historical understanding of the dynamics that inform the relationship between the Islamic world and Western civilization in the present time. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HUMS
title: Women in the Ancient World
description: Introduction to the roles of women in ancient Egyptian, Mesopotamian, and Aegean society, as reflected in painting, sculpture, and decorative arts, as well as in the earliest known writings of women. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: HUMS
title: Rome
description: Offered in Rome, Italy. Designed as the logical complement and correlation to HUMS 444, this course will consider how Rome's contributions to Western thought are recorded in the very fabric of the city. Open to Yale students only. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rome, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Prerequisite: HUMS 444. Enrollment limited, with preference to Humanities majors and juniors. For further information please please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: June 1 - July 5.

subject: HUMS
title: Studio Practice in Painting an...
long_title: Studio Practice in Painting and Drawing
description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students from liberal arts and fine arts backgrounds with or without prior experience. Studio Practice is an intensive study of painting and drawing focusing on the dynamics of the artist's studio practice of developing and constructing work. It is crafted for those who wish to study and experience the intimate process of personal idea imaging through the language of painting and drawing. Of great importance to the course is the development of strategies necessary for individual discovery, observation/analysis,and relational thinking. The residential program demands commitment, a strong work ethic and study within a 24/7 curriculum. All applicants should consult Robert Reed prior to completing the online application. Enrollment is limited to 15 participants. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: June 1 - June 29.

subject: HUMS
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent; and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: July 5 - August 9.

subject: IDRS
title: Independent Research in the Sc...
description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a one- or two-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: IDRS
title: Independent Research in the Sc...
description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a one- or two-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian I
description: Eight weeks in Grado (CRN: 30135), or three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena (CRN: 30134). An intensive course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students will be able to choose a preference in the application of the Siena or Grado programs, but will be assigned to either as necessary because of seats available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Grado, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120 (in Grado CRN: 30138, in Siena CRN: 30137). Credit only on completion of ITAL S120. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: May 31 - July 26.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian I
description: Eight weeks in Grado (CRN: 30135), or three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena (CRN: 30134). An intensive course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students will be able to choose a preference in the application of the Siena or Grado programs, but will be assigned to either as necessary because of seats available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Grado, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120 (in Grado CRN: 30138, in Siena CRN: 30137). Credit only on completion of ITAL S120. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: May 31 - July 26.

subject: ITAL
title: Italian Language and Cinema in...
long_title: Italian Language and Cinema in Tuscany
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisà. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: June 21 - July 26.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian II
description: Eight weeks in Grado (CRN: 30138), or three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena (CRN: 30137). An intensive course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students will be able to choose a preference in the application of the Siena or Grado programs, but will be assigned to either as necessary because of seats available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Grado, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S110 (in Grado CRN: 30135, in Siena CRN: 30134). For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: May 31 - July 26.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian II
description: Eight weeks in Grado (CRN: 30138), or three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena (CRN: 30137). An intensive course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students will be able to choose a preference in the application of the Siena or Grado programs, but will be assigned to either as necessary because of seats available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Grado, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S110 (in Grado CRN: 30135, in Siena CRN: 30134). For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: May 31 - July 26.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian I
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Open to Yale students only. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL 140. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent. Credit only on completion of ITAL S140. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 11/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian II
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Open to Yale students only. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL 130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Prerequisite: ITAL 130 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 11/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: ITAL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Offered in Siena, Italy. A critical reading, in Italian, of Dante's Divina Commedia, and the Vita nova. This course will place the two works in the moral, political, artistic and intellectual context of the City of Florence at the end of the thirteenth century by relating these major texts to parallel concerns Dante shared with other Florentine artist, intellectuals, and poets. Prerequisite: Open to students who passed ITAL 140 or 145 (L4) or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 21 - July 26.

subject: LATN
title: Beginning Latin: The Elements...
long_title: Beginning Latin: The Elements of Grammar
description: Introduction to Latin. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for LATN 120. No prior knowledge of Latin assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: LATN
title: Beginning Latin: Review of Gra...
long_title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
description: Continuation of LATN 110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Latin authors. The sequence LATN 110, 120 prepares for 131 or 141. Prerequisite: LATN 110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: LATN
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Readings in Latin of approximately two books of Virgil's Aeneid with an introduction to Virgilian grammar, vocabulary, and context. Prerequisite: completion of an introductory course in Latin (LATN 110 and 120). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: LING
title: Language in America
description: A survey of language and linguistic variation in the Americas from prehistoric times to contemporary society. Native American languages; European colonial languages; contact languages; North American English dialects; social, ethnic, and gender variation in speech. Introduction to concepts in language contact and change, language geography, dialectology, and sociolinguistics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: LING
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. The study of language from the perspective of cognitive science. Exploration of the mental structures that underlie our ability to learn and process language, drawing on studies of normal and atypical language development and processing, brain imaging, neuropsychology, and computational modeling. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: LING
title: History of Hebrew & Jewish Lan...
description: Cultural, historical, and linguistic aspects of the Hebrew and Jewish languages. How Yiddish and other Jewish languages emerged. Introduction to a multitude of linguistic technologies to include the historical-comparative method and the family tree model. Some knowledge of linguistics and/or Hebrew would be helpful, but not necessary. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: LITR
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Examination of how stories are told in both literary and nonliterary texts, with special attention to the act of decoding and interpreting a narrative. Emphasis on fictional form, the mechanics of plot, and questions of time and character. Topics include confession, memory, language, the representation of the self, the interplay of form and content, and the relationship between fiction and history. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: LITR
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: LITR
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent; and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information please visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: July 5 - August 9.

subject: LITR
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Holocaust: Rhetoric, Film, and Politics
description: Cancelled. Political, cultural, and ideological background of the Holocaust and its representation in film, art and literature. Relationship of Nazi thought to culture, science, and technology. Aesthetics as the backbone and public face of the Holocaust. Will consider Kant, Nietzsche, Wagner, Heidegger, Kafka, Riefenstahl, Celan, Levi, Hersonski, Lanzmann, Quentin Tarantino. Readings and discussion in English. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: LITR
title: Belle Époque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,700. Course dates: May 31 - July 5

subject: LITR
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: LITR
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. How short fictions condense meaning into concise and precise structure of plot and character. How stories establish a spatial and temporal environment for characters and why readers make judgments about charcters by their actions. Point of view and subjects such as the Gothic psyche and gendered narratives will be discussed. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: MATH
title: CalcOfFunctionsOfeVariable I
description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should enroll in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra and pre-calculus. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus of Functions of One V...
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
description: A continuation of MATH 112. The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Functions of S...
long_title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
description: Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus of Functions of Sever...
long_title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. After MATH 115 or with permission of instructor. May not be taken after MATH 121. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: MCDB
title: Neurobiology of Memory
description: Introductory survey of multidisciplinary approaches to studying the neurobiology of memory. Current conception of memory mechanisms and contributions of the fields of molecular and cell biology, psychology, neuroscience, genetics, and physics will be discussed. Some previous coursework in Biology is required. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: MCDB
title: Laboratory for Principles of M...
long_title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cell, and Developmental Biology
description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. Must be taken after BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or after BIOL S105. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,725. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: MCDB
title: Cell Biology
description: A comprehensive course in cell and molecular biology.  Emphasis on general principles of cell function and rationale and design of pertinent biomedical experiments. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or BIOL S105, or permission of the instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: MMES
title: Islam and the West
description: Historical survey of the key points of contact, exchange, and contention between Islam and the Christian West from the early medieval to the modern period. Students will gain a historical understanding of the dynamics that inform the relationship between the Islamic world and Western civilization in the present time. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: MMES
title: Art and Revolution in the Mode...
long_title: Art and Revolution in the Modern Middle East
description: Explores the intersection of modern art and political upheaval during the last two centuries in the Modern Middle East. Spans from Napoleon's invasion of Egypt in 1798, tracing a trajectory of fine arts and visual culture in the region, to the graffiti, cartoons, and social media of the Arab Spring. Focuses on questions of the impact of political change on art and visual culture; the role of ethnicity, gender, and class in modern Middle Eastern art; and the lasting mark of colonialism, post-colonialism, and neo-colonialism on the region. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: MUS
title: Introduction to the Analysis o...
long_title: Introduction to the Analysis of Nontonal Music
description: Offered Online. MUS 558E, Introduction to the Analysis of Nontonal Music4 credits. NP. Group B. This course consists of the examination of various analytic techniques and their use in the analysis of music by Krenek, Dallapiccola, Lutoslawski, Stravinsky, Webern, and Whittenberg. Helpful, but not a prerequisite, is some prior exposure to Schenker analysis and a knowledge of the fundamentals of set theory. Session: June 16-July 18.

subject: MUSI
title: Listening to Classical Music
description: Offered Online. Do you like the sound of classical music but have always been mystified, even intimidated by it? Then this experience is for you. This course will explain the elements of classical music in simple terms using engaging, fun exercises. Once the basics are in place, we explore the full panoply of classical music, from Bach to Beethoven to Bernstein, employing pop music along the way to explain the workings of the classical masterpieces. Students need not read musical notation or know anything about classical music. The only prerequisites: a willingness to hear new sounds and a desire think about what makes great music. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: MUSI
title: Jazz and Race in America
description: Offered Online. A study of the evolution of jazz, from its precursors in the music of Africa through its beginnings in New Orleans to its fusion with rock in the 1970s. Jazz's greatest artists and their styles are presented with selected music of each jazz period and a discussion of the racial and sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: NELC
title: Women in the Ancient World
description: Introduction to the roles of women in ancient Egyptian, Mesopotamian, and Aegean society, as reflected in painting, sculpture, and decorative arts, as well as in the earliest known writings of women. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: NHTL
title: Intensive Nahuatl Language and...
description: An intensive immersion course designed to familiarize students with modern and colonia Nahuatl. Beginning-, intermediate-, and advanced-level students may apply. Formal class hours are complemented with individual practice sessions and group cultural activities. Partial scholarships are available. Details on the Yale Latin American Iberian Studies website, http://www.yale.edu/macmillan/lais/summer.html, or contact Jean Silk, jean.silk@yale.edu, for further information. Open to undergraduate and graduate students. 3 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Program dates: June 23 - August 1.

subject: NURS
title: Sem in Comm Hlth Nur & PH: Com...
long_title: Sem in Comm Hlth Nur & PH: Comm Hlth Nursing & PH
description: 2 credit hours. Sessions explore the multidisciplinary theoretical foundations that are the basis for community health nursing practice across the life span. Topics include history of community health nursing and public health science; structure and function of federal, state, and local health organizations; funding mechanisms for community health care; epidemiological and biostatistical indicators of community health; methods of family and community analyses. Required for all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Practice in Maternal-...
description: 2 credit hours. This course focuses on clinical practice essential to nursing care of women, newborns, and their families throughout the childbearing cycle and the neonatal period. Clinical settings include hospital and ambulatory care. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Seminar in Maternal-Newborn Nu...
description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to the provision of nursing care to childbearing families throughout the childbearing cycle, the neonatal period, and the pre- and inter-conceptional phases. Application of the nursing process as it relates to the promotion, maintenance, and restoration of health is emphasized. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Practice in Pediatric...
description: 2 credit hours. Utilizing a family-centered approach, this course provides clinical experience in identifying and assessing children's physiological and developmental needs, and planning, implementing, and evaluating a plan of nursing care to meet the needs of a particular child and his/her family in health care settings. Students have opportunities to use principles of growth and development, knowledge of the child's and family's physical and emotional responses to illness, and principles of pediatric nursing in caring for children and their families. The student gains skill and knowledge in the nursing role and an appreciation for the importance of utilizing research findings in practice and collaborating with other health professionals. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Seminar in Pediatric Nursing
description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to promote health and adaptation to illness for children and their families. Emphasis is placed on growth and development, as well as pathophysiological, social, environmental, and cultural factors that influence children's and families' response to health and illness. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Primary Care of Children I
description: 2 credit hours per term. This course provides clinical experience in well-child care and management of common pediatric problems in a variety of primary care settings. Students provide primary health care, acute care, and beginning case management for pediatric patients in the context of their families. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of pediatric nurse practitioner students in the first year of specialization. Four and one-half hours in a clinical setting and one and one-half to two hours per week of clinical conference.

subject: NURS
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Master's Independent Study: Sklld Birth Attndnce in Haiti
description: Cancelled. This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.

subject: NURS
title: Master's Independent Study: Cl...
long_title: Master's Independent Study: Clinical Practicum in ICU Nurs
description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.

subject: NURS
title: Master's Independent Study: Pl...
long_title: Master's Independent Study: Plant Based Health 2
description: This elective study is initiated by the student and negotiated with faculty. The purpose is to allow in-depth pursuit of individual areas of interest and/or practice. A written proposal must be submitted and signed by the student, the faculty member(s), and the appropriate specialty director. Credit varies according to the terms of the contract.

subject: NURS
title: Adv Clin Prac for A/F/G&WH NPs
long_title: Adv Clin Prac for A/F/G&WH NPs
description:
3.2–5.8 credit hours. This clinical course builds upon the experiences gained in 556b and provides students further opportunity to develop advanced nursing skills, clinical judgment, and evidence-based patient management strategies necessary to manage common acute and chronic health care conditions. Students participate in designated weekly primary care clinical experiences arranged by faculty. In addition, students meet weekly for a one-and-one-half-hour clinical conference that is held concurrently with clinical practice. Clinical seminar discussions for family nurse practitioner students focus on family-centered care and providing care for patients across the life span. Clinical seminar discussions for all other students focus on providing patient-centered care for patients from adolescence to senescence. Clinical conference serves as a forum for students to present and discuss cases and explore issues encountered in clinical practice. Required of adult/gerontological, family, and women's health nurse practitioner students in the final year. Eight to sixteen hours of clinical practice per week (fifteen weeks), and one and one-half hours of clinical conference per week (each term).
Taken concurrently with 757a/b and, for family nurse practitioners, with 833a/b. Prerequisite (or concurrent with): 556b.

subject: NURS
title: Primary Care of Children II
description:
2 credit hours per term. This course provides clinical experience in advanced pediatric primary care and management, including work with complex families. The student provides health care for children over the course of the year in the Primary Care Center, Yale-New Haven Hospital, and at selected pediatric primary care sites in the community. Required of pediatric nurse practitioner students in the final year of specialization. Four and one-half hours clinical practice per week and one and one-half hours clinical conference per week.
Prerequisite: successful completion of 632a/b.

subject: NURS
title: Specialty Pediatric Clinical P...
description: 1.7 credit hours. This clinical practicum provides students with the opportunity to gain additional knowledge and experience in specialty practice areas with relevance to pediatric primary care. Required of pediatric nurse practitioner students in the final year of specialization, usually taken during the spring term. A second term may be taken as an elective in the final year with permission of the course instructor and faculty adviser. Four and one-half hours of clinical practice per week and eight hours of clinical conference.

subject: PHIL
title: Happiness
description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time, examining how new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea; whether happiness should be a goal in life; the relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy
description: Introduction to the history and methods of philosophical reflection and inquiry. Exploration of several perennial philosophical issues and the distinctive ways of addressing these issues through a close reading of historical texts and group discussion. Readings include selections from the works of Plato, Aristotle, Hume, Kant, Mill, and twentieth-century philosophers. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PHIL
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee $85. Offered in Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30233) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRN: 30234).

subject: PHIL
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Technology fee $85. Offered in Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30233) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRN: 30234).

subject: PHIL
description: Introduction to problems and methods in the philosophy of law. The nature of law and legal authority; political questions regarding the nature of rights and limitations on freedom; issues in criminal law, tort law, and contract law. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PHIL
title: International Ethics
description: Overview of central ethical questions within the global arena. Topics include international governance, just war, human rights, genocide, global justice, humanitarian intervention, and economic sanctions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PHIL
title: Eastern Philosophy
description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, the self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PHIL
title: Environmental Ethics
description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PHIL
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PHYS
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non–science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PHYS
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 25 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S150, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students and beyond. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,725. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S151, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students and beyond. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,725. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics for the Lif...
long_title: University Physics for the Life Sciences
description: An introduction to classical physics with special emphasis on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Topics include electricity and magnetism, circuits, light and optics, sound, and modern physics. essential calculus is introduced as needed. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B (July 7 - August 8).

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, waves, and thermodynamics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.Â  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers electromagnetism, optics, special relativity, and quantum physics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.Â  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. Prerequisite: PHYS 180 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC
title: Introduction to Political Phil...
description: Issues of liberty, equality, and justice considered from within the Western tradition of political philosophy. Readings from Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC
title: Introduction to Human Rights T...
long_title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PLSC
title: Foreign Policy and Internation...
description: This six-week course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities Global Summer Program. Two students from each partner university, including two from Yale, will be admitted to this course. Partial funding is provided for all students enrolled. The course will cover the mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and of the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 29 - August 8.

subject: PLSC
title: U.S. Strategy After the Cold War
long_title: U.S. Strategy After the Cold War
description: American grand strategy since the collapse of the Soviet Union. The ability of the United States to project its power around the world. Constraints on and challenges to American power in the international political system. The effect of nuclear weapons on the workings of a unipolar world. The possible emergence of peer competitors in the future. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PLSC
title: International Human Rights and...
description: International human rights bodies and their implications for international politics. The role of human rights institutions in affording remedies to victims of state abuse. The emergence and exercise of international human rights law, including its nature, mechanisms, and logic. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PLSC
title: International Ethics
description: Overview of central ethical questions within the global arena. Topics include international governance, just war, human rights, genocide, global justice, humanitarian intervention, and economic sanctions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC
title: Political Journalism and its I...
long_title: Political Journalism and its Impact on Public Policy
description: Questions about how journalism influences public policy, the traditional model of print journalism versus advances in technology and changes in our culture. Examines how the media affect policy decisions made by elected officials and influences political campaigns. Examples from Connecticut's General Assembly, including its efforts to repeal the death penalty in 2012 and enact gun control reform in the wake of the Newtown school shooting. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC
title: Crime and Punishment
description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Focus on various theories of criminal process in light of empirical evidence, the politicization of crime, civil rights issues, psychiatry and the law, abortion, and arguments about prison reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC
title: Reading the Constitution
description: Offered Online. Intensive introduction to the written Constitution, revolving tightly around two books authored by the instructor--America's Constitution: A Biography (2005) and America's Unwritten Constitution: The Precedents and Principles We Live By (2012). Provides detailed knowledge of America's written Constitution and considers various techniques of constitutional interpretation. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30219) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRN: 30220).

subject: PLSC
title: Reading the Constitution
description: Offered Online. Intensive introduction to the written Constitution, revolving tightly around two books authored by the instructor--America's Constitution: A Biography (2005) and America's Unwritten Constitution: The Precedents and Principles We Live By (2012). Provides detailed knowledge of America's written Constitution and considers various techniques of constitutional interpretation. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: June 2 - July 4 (CRN: 30219) and Session B: July 7 - August 8 (CRN: 30220).

subject: PLSC
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. A survey of the historical development of the executive branch of the American national government; an examination of the politics of presidential leadership; and consideration of how the development of the executive branch has affected presidential politics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PLSC
title: Terrorism, Law, Morality
description: Legal and moral issues in democracies' responses to terrorism. What the term "terrorism" denotes and why and when it is used; U.S. law regarding material support for terrorism; the targeted killing of persons in a global battlefield; how terrorism compares morally to other forms of political violence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC
title: Environmental Ethics
description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PLSC
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PLSC
title: Ethnic Conflict
description: Causes of ethnic conflict and its most violent forms, including ethnic civil war. Critically reviews the dominant explanations of ethnic conflict and applies them to actual cases, including current examples of ethnic war, to arrive at an in-depth understanding of the problem and consider some of its solutions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session A: June 2 - July 4.

subject: PLSC
title: War and Constitutions
description: Examines the historical record from ancient times to the present to understand how wars have shaped the nation state, including structures of accountability and political rights. Provides students with the analytical and empirical tools for understanding the effects of war on constitutional structures across time and place. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PORT
title: Elementary Portuguese for Spea...
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages I
description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S122 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: knowledge of another Romance language. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: PORT
title: Elementary Portuguese for Spea...
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages II
description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: knowledge of another Romance language. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,600. Course Dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: First four weeks in Sao Jose do Rio Preto, Sao Paulo, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in Portuguese. Includes visiting the city of Sao Paulo and the state of Minas Gerais to provide a broader perspective of modern Brazil. Immersion in the language with exposure and active participation in diverse activities such as visits to industries, trade schools, after-school activities, lectures, and historic tours. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S140. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent. Credit only on completion of PORT S140. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 1 - July 26.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: First four weeks in SÃ£o Jose do Rio Preto, SÃ£o Paulo, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in Portuguese. Includes visiting the city of SÃ£o Paulo and the state of Minas Gerais to provide a broader perspective of modern Brazil. Immersion in the language with exposure and active participation in diverse activities such as visits to industries, trade schools, after-school activities, lectures, and historic tours. An intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S130. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 1 - July 26.

subject: PORT
title: Introduction to Brazil
description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in English with sessions in Portuguese. An introduction to Brazilian cultural history from 1500 to the present. Essential themes and figures for understanding modern Brazil. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112/S122. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session Study Abroad website. 1 Credit. Tuition: See PORT S112/S122 for tuition. Course Dates: June 2 - July 26.

subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology
description: Offered Online. A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,450. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 7 - August 8.

subject: PSYC
